did.unittitle: Time Inc. Fortune Publishing and Business Records

physdesc.extent: in 45 record cartons including 6 reels of microfilm and 1 document case

did.abstract: The Fortune Publishing and Business Records contain materials from the offices and staff of the business and publishing side of the magazine's operation. The majority of materials are records from from the office of Publisher William Geer; advertiser record cards; and records from the offices of public affairs and promotions.
did.physloc: Materials in this collection are stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This record group is arranged in four series:
Series I. Publisher William Geer Files
Series II. Public Relations Department Files
Series III. Advertising Sales Department Records
Series IV. Fortune Data Bank Publications Fulfillment Files

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: For the majority of Time Inc.'s existence, the company maintained a strict separation of editorial from the publishing and business side of each magazine, colloquially called the separation of "church" (editorial) and "state" (publishing). Publishing and Business Management includes the publisher, general manager, business manager, advertising sales, marketing services, letters, circulation, and public relations. The editorial side reported up to the editor-in-chief and the publishing/business side reported up to the corporate business executive which was the president prior to 1960 and the chief executive officer after. Henry Luce structured Time Inc. this way so that the business side could not (in theory) influence the editorial content of the publications. For example, the advertising sales people could not interfere with a magazine's decision to run an article on the dangers of cigarette smoking, even though it might mean losing millions of dollars in tobacco ads.

In September 1928, Time Inc. cofounder Henry Luce presented cofounder Briton Hadden with an idea for a new magazine. Luce wanted to create a magazine that would cater to the men who ran businesses in the United States. This magazine would offer business men a sophisticated perspective on industrial business and its role in society. To cater to this clientele, the magazine would feature richly illustrated pages as well as high quality editorial content. Hadden was not convinced that Luce's idea would work but agreed to let Parker Lloyd-Smith, a business writer at Time, and some researchers explore Luce's idea. In February 1929, not long after Hadden's sudden death, Luce went to the board of Time Inc. with his idea and proposed the launch of Fortune. At this meeting, Luce presented the board with a description of the magazine's appearance and an outline of its contents. This outline included samples of some articles that had already been written as well as illustrations. A few months after Fortune was proposed, the board agreed to proceed with the idea and the first issue of the magazine was released in February 1930.

Much like with Time, Luce named himself Fortune's editor. One of the first editorial decisions that Luce made was about how financial news would be presented. In other magazines and newspapers with similar content, facts and statistics were present in a straightforward fashion with no embellishment. To change this, Luce decided to hire literary talent instead of business experts or economists. Some of the talent that was recruited overs the years to work on Fortune included James Agee, John Kenneth Galbraith, Ernest Hemingway, Alfred Kazin, Dwight Macdonald, Archibald MacLeish, and Miné Okubo. Because Fortune was taking a more literary approach to its content, there were human interest stories alongside in-depth articles about major businesses and industries. In addition to the change in editorial material, Fortune also changed the approach to the advertisements and images used in the magazine. Instead of the standard black and white images, there was an emphasis on colorful advertisements and striking art, illustrations, and photographs. To make the imagery in the magazine stand out, Fortune recruited well-known artists and photographers. Included among those who have worked for Fortune over the years are Ansel Adams, Constantin Alajálov, John Atherton, Herbert Bayer, Lester Beal, Thomas Benrimo, Joseph Binder, Margaret Bourke-White, A.M. Cassandre, Thomas Maitland Cleland, Miguel Covarrubias, Walker Evans, George Gusti, Fernand Léger, Fred Ludekens, Erik Nitsche, Antonio Petruccelli, Diego Rivera, Ben Shahn, and Charles Sheeler. To receive a copy of this newly released magazine, members of the public needed to become subscribers. Despite there being no focus groups or trial issues to introduce buyers to the product, there were 30,000 subscribers at the time of the magazine's release. The initial copies cost $1 each or $10 for a yearly subscription. At the time, this was a steep price and was meant to act as a barrier so that only the most passionate and well off customers could afford to read it.

Fortune was well received by critics and industry professionals alike. By the end of 1930 and the release of the first eleven issues, the magazine's circulation had increased by 10,000 and was turning a profit for Time Inc. Despite the strong start, Fortune suffered difficulties after the end of World War II and was beginning to become unprofitable. At the same time that the magazine was experiencing financial trouble, members of Fortune's board of editors started to believe that the magazine was suffering from problems on the editorial side as well. Members of the board of editors suggested that the magazine had a lack of cohesion and no new ideas. Upon hearing these doubts, Luce decided to make some changes to the magazine and change its focus. The magazine would provide guidance to those interested in America's political economy. The changes upset the magazine's editors and writers, but renewed the interest of businessmen and helped increase the magazine's circulation.

Despite this somewhat tumultuous beginning, Fortune is still in print as of 2018. Over time the magazine has changed its publication schedule. Originally a monthly publications, the magazine became a bi-weekly publication in 1978 but switched to tri-weekly publication in 2009. While the magazine is primarily published in the United States, the magazine has had international editions as well. Many of these editions are no longer in print. These changes in Fortune's publication schedule coincided with an increase in demand for the magazine. With the growth of the magazine's popularity with the general public, editors and writers from Fortune began to make appearances on radio and television shows to share information found in the latest articles. The magazine also hosted its own short-lived television show Fortune Week which was on CNBC from 1993 to 1994.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers with the exception of restricted materials. Restricted materials may include contracts and consent forms. Restricted boxes include R42, 2868, 2911-2913, and 2919-2942. Unreformatted audiovisual and digital material in the collection is not accessible. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is owned by the New-York Historical Society. Although the N-YHS owns this collection as physical property, the donor specifically retains all copyright and all other proprietary rights which may exist. The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as Time Inc. Fortune Publishing and Business Records, MS 3009-RG 25, New York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Time Inc. Fortune Publishing and Business Records were processed by Samantha Brown in 2018 and 2019. The original folders were retained although some documents were transferred to archival containers in the instances of overcrowding or if no original folders were present. Brown created the inventory and other descriptive notes for the record. Series were created based on the original arrangement of the materials. Within series, materials were arranged in their original order. Files retained their original titles but files with illegible writing or unclear titles were either assigned new titles or had information added to them to clarify the contents.
Holly Deakyne processed the addition of the microfilm in the Advertising Sales Department Records in 2019 and updated the finding aid.
Deakyne processed the Fortune Data Bank Publication Fulfillment Files in 2021 and updated the finding aid.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: This finding aid relates to just one record group of the Time Inc. Records. For information about the other record groups and for overall information about the archives, please see the Guide to the Time Inc. Records (MS 3009). The Henry Luce Papers (MS 3014) were acquired with the Time Inc. Records. The collection of books acquired with the records are cataloged as the Time Inc. Reference Library.

Information about the history of Fortune and additional records from the publishing and business offices can be found in the Time Inc. Subject Files (MS 3009-RG 1) and the Time Inc. Annex Files (MS 3009-RG 39). Records from the editorial offices are in the Time Inc. Fortune Editorial Records (MS 3009-RG 8).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Fortune Publishing and Business Records contain records from offices and staff from the publishing and business side of the magazine, not the editorial side. The staff represented include Publisher William Geer and Public Relations Director Emma Dockendorff. Additionally, there are departmental records from Advertising Sales and Public Relations along with collected audiovisual material relating to Fortune. This record group includes clippings, correspondence, notes, transcripts, drafts, press releases, press kits, photographs, video cassettes, audio cassettes, and open audio reels.

did.unittitle: Series I. Publisher William Geer Files

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: William Geer began working for Time Inc. as writer in 1929 after graduating from Yale. During his time as a writer, Geer assisted with the March of Time radio shows. In 1939, Geer was promoted to promotion manager for Time Inc. but changed positions the following year and became the assistant to the president. Geer remained in this position for two years before beginning to work for Fortune. It is unclear what Geer's first position with Fortune was. Some materials indicate that he worked as a general manager from 1942 to 1943 while others have him listed as a publisher for all seven years that he worked for Fortune. In 1949, Geer left Fortune and became associate publisher of Life. During his time as associate publisher, Geer also acted as a producer of the television series Crusade in Europe, which ran from 1950-1951 and was an attempted relaunched of the March of Time film series. In 1954, Geer retired from Time Inc.
Citations:

"William Geer Sr. of Time Inc. Dead." New York Times. August 23, 1976. Accessed January 3, 2019. https://www.nytimes.com/1976/08/23/archives/william-geer-sr-of-time-inc-dead-fortune-and-life-official-70-with.html
Personnel and Organization: Department Head Lists. Time Inc. Reference Files (MS 3009-RG 3), The New-York Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Publisher William Geer files were created or collected by Geer during his time working for Fortune from 1942 to 1949 and contain materials from 1929 to 1949. Materials that date prior to 1942 are items that Geer used for reference. Additionally, Geer's files include materials from Richardson Wood, a member of Fortune's board of editors beginning in 1940. While Time Inc. in general kept a strict separation between the editorial and publishing sides of their enterprises, materials within this series indicate that Wood and Geer sent materials between each other and may have collaborated on some projects together.

Materials in the series include lists of Fortune advertisers, lists of ad agencies, advertising order policy, drafts of ads and page layouts, answers to common questions about the ad department, chart of circulation expenses, clippings, plans for senior Fortune writers, department of labor reports, financial statements, outlines of department objectives, reports on circulation fulfillment, reports on circulation demographic problems, reports on the future of Time Inc., edit formula/plans, reports on operations, reports on comments concerning Fortune, and correspondence. The topics discussed in the correspondence include Fortune circulation, public perception of Fortune, new ad accounts, number of ads, estimated ad revenue, magazine ideas, meetings, complaints about Fortune ads, expenses, budgets, salaries, Newspaper Guild negotiations and election surveys.

Series II. Public Relations Department Files

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The earliest records of the Fortune Public Relations department are from 1987 and show Gary Belis as the department head. While the documents themselves do not list his exact role, the Time Inc. department heads list shows Belis as the head of the Publicity department. There is no indication, within the records or in any department heads list, of this department existing before 1987 though it may have been a part of another department, such as Promotions. Looking within the files themselves does not clear up this issue either since the work of Public Relations and Promotions appears to overlap. In 1991, the department was renamed the Public Relations Department. Between 1987 and 1991, there does not appear to be a consistent name for the department. In general, materials within the collection indicate that employees used the names Publicity, Public Affairs, and Public Relations interchangeably.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Public Relations Department Files contain materials created or collected by employees within the department between 1987 and 1991. Included in the series are clippings, transcripts, press releases, press kits, photographs, negatives, transparencies, pamphlets, reports, and correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged into five subseries:
Subseries II.A. Public Relations Director Emma Dockendorff
Subseries II.B. Public Relations Office Files
Subseries II.C. Press Releases
Subseries II.D. Television and Radio Transcript Files
Subseries II.E. Newspaper, Radio, and Television Clippings Files

did.unittitle: Subseries II.A. Public Relations Director Emma Dockendorff

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Emma Dockendorff was Fortune's Director of Public Relations between 1989 and 1993. Prior to her work at Time Inc., Dockendorff worked as an independent public relations and marketing consultant.
Citations:
"Emma Clurman, a Consultant, Marries." New York Times. May 18, 1985. Accessed January 03, 2019. https://www.nytimes.com/1985/05/18/style/emma-clurman-a-consultant-marries.html.
Fortune Magazine Masthead. January 11, 1993. Vol. 127, No. 1. Accessed January 07, 2019. http://archive.fortune.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1993/01/11/77385/index.htm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Public Relations Director Emma Dockendorff files cover the period of 1989 to 1991. The focus of the subseries is on managing the public's perception of Fortune, setting up seminars and events, and overseeing the work done within Fortune's Public Relations department. Included in this subseries are lists of public relations firms, clippings, lists of employees and responsibilities, lists of major ad market papers ranked by circulation, lists of sources for news about magazines, lists of major news syndicates, seminar schedules, to-do lists and notes, reports on broadcast market analysis, pamphlets from Quality Workforce Forum, press releases, Time Warner quarterly reports, lists and report on leading advertisers, reports on CEO crisis management and communication, photographs from 60th anniversary events, press kits, press releases and correspondence. The topics covered by the correspondence includes policies for sales and marketing staff, press release policies, ad sales, circulation statistics, and seminars.

did.unittitle: Fortune Holds 20th Annual Worldwide Corporate Communications Seminar
Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory and Time Warner Corporate Information Packet
Subseries II.B. Public Relations Office Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Public Relations Office Files focus on events that the Public Relations department helped arrange as well as material collected by the department documenting the public's perception of Fortune. Staff represented include Francine Uomoleale, Gary Belis, and Emma Dockendorff. Records include job descriptions, invoices, press and radio reports, press kits, photographs, negatives, and clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Press Releases were collected by the Public Relations department between 1989 and 1990. These press releases announced special issues of Fortune or articles that were soon to be published. The dates on files indicate the date of an issue's or article's publication rather than when a press release was distributed.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.D. Television and Radio Transcript Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Radio and Television Transcript files cover the period of 1990 to 1991 and include transcripts from Fortune editors' appearances on radio and television programs. The specific shows included in this subseries are Inside Business and Your Dollar. Additionally, there are transcripts from editor appearances on the Financial News Network.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.E. Newspaper, Radio, and Television Clippings Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Newspaper, Radio, and Television Clippings Files cover the period of 1989 to 1991 and includes collected newspaper clippings as wells as transcripts of radio and television shows that mention specific issues of Fortune or featured articles. The folder titles appear to relate to specific issues of Fortune rather than the dates of the clippings. of a specific clipping was published.

did.unittitle: Series III. Advertising Sales Department Records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Advertising Sales Deparment Records contains the Fortune Advertiser Record Cards which are are on microfilm. The dates refer to the original material and not the creation of the microfilm. Each record card contains the magazine issue date for the advertisement, size of ad, if it is in black-and-white or color, and the cost.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized alphabetically by name of company or organization placing ad, not the name of the product.

did.unittitle: Series IV. Fortune Data Bank Publications Fulfillment Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fortune Data Bank Publications Fulfillment Files contains a sampling of requests from readers to purchase other publications by Fortune advertised in the magazine. These include editorial studies, market surveys, directories, and conference reports designed to "give you an edge in expertise, get you more for your management money." Publications include "Business and Banking", "Crosscurrents", "DDP Decisions", "Double 500 Directory", "Why Corporate America Moves Where", "Working Smarter", and "World Business Directory".

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized alphabetically based on the original arrangement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Audiovisual series covers the period of 1978 to 2005 and contains audiovisual materials that were collected by promotions, publicity, public affairs, and public relations staff. The majority of materials document Fortune editors' appearances on television as well as events hosted by the magazine. All subseries are based on the original arrangement of the materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This series contains six subseries:
Subseries V.A. Fortune Editors on TV
Subseries V.B. Fortune Satellite Press Tours
Subseries V.C. Fortune Week
Subseries V.D. Wall Street Week with Fortune
Subseries V.E. Miscellaneous
Subseries V.F. Box Labels

did.unittitle: Subseries V.A. Fortune Editors on TV

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Fortune Editors on TV subseries covers the period of 1992 to 2001. Contained within this subseries are videotaoes which document Fortune editor and writer appearances on television shows. Additionally, there is one audiocassette with the audio of an editor appearance on a television show.

did.unittitle: Subseries V.B. Fortune Satellite Press Tours

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Fortune Satellite Press Tours subseries covers the period of 1992 to 1996. This subseries contains copies of videotapes that were distributed to television stations. These tapes usually had recordings of interviews with or statements made by Fortune editors or writers on specific topics, such as the Fortune 500 or Investors Guide.

did.unittitle: Subseries V.D. Wall Street Week with Fortune

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Originally launched as Wall Street Week with Louis Rukeyser in 1972, the show ran under this name from 1972 to 2002. During a revamp in 2002, original host, Louis Rukeyser, was replaced in an attempt to attract a younger audience. Relaunched as Wall Street Week with Fortune, it was now a joint venture between Fortune, Maryland Public Television, and PBS. The new hosts of the show were Geoffrey Colvin, the editorial director of Fortune, and Karen Gibbs, who was previously a senior business correspondent for Fox News. The host, along with panelists, would discuss financial markets, the economy, and financial issues in an attempt to help keep investors informed about developments. Despite attempts to grow the audience, the show was canceled in 2005.
Citations:

Ives, Nat. "'Wall St. Week,' a PBS Staple, Will Go Off the Air in June." The New York Times. March 24, 2005. Accessed January 04, 2019. https://www.nytimes.com/2005/03/24/business/media/wall-st-week-a-pbs-staple-will-go-off-the-air-in-june.html
"Wall $treet Week with Fortune." IMDb. Accessed January 04, 2019. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0346443/
"Wall $treet Week with Louis Rukeyser." IMDb. Accessed January 04, 2019. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0255766/

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous subseries contains materials from 1978 to 2004 and include recordings of employee interviews, events, seminars, ads, training and orientation videos, and mentions of Fortune in the media. These recordings are mainly on U-matic and VHS cassettes but Betacam and Betamax cassettes are also included as well as open reel audiotapes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains box labels that were placed originally glued to the outside of the audiovisual boxes. Since the labels were beginning to fall off, the labels were removed from the boxes and placed in folders within their original box. The labels have information about the original contents of the box as well as information about the transfer of the boxes from their original department to Time Inc.'s archives.
